cards.name: Soul Tithe
cards.text:
Enchant nonland permanent
At the beginning of the upkeep of enchanted permanent's controller, that player sacrifices it unless they pay {X}, where X is its converted mana cost.

rulings.text: The converted mana cost of a creature token is 0, unless that token is a copy of another creature, in which case it copies that creature's mana cost.
If the permanent has {X} in its mana cost, X is 0.

cards.originalText:
Enchant nonland permanent
At the beginning of the upkeep of enchanted permanent's controller, that player sacrifices it unless he or she pays {X}, where X is its converted mana cost.

cards.name: Sphere of Safety
cards.text: Creatures can't attack you or a planeswalker you control unless their controller pays {X} for each of those creatures, where X is the number of enchantments you control.
cards.flavor: The Rakdos believe that all are eager to join their revels, even when told otherwise.

rulings.text: If you control Sphere of Safety, your opponents can choose not to attack with a creature with an ability that says it attacks if able.

cards.originalText: Creatures can't attack you or a planeswalker you control unless their controller pays {X} for each of those creatures, where X is the number of enchantments you control.

cards.name: Sunspire Griffin
cards.text: Flying
cards.flavor:
"For each griffin wounded by an arrow, there's a corpse with a bow nearby."
—Pel Javya, Wojek investigator

foreignNames.name: Griffon de la Tour de Phébus

cards.originalText: Flying

cards.name: Swift Justice
cards.text: Until end of turn, target creature gets +1/+0 and gains first strike and lifelink.
cards.flavor:
"Having conviction is more important than being righteous."
—Aurelia
cards.originalText: Until end of turn, target creature gets +1/+0 and gains first strike and lifelink.

cards.name: Trained Caracal
cards.text: Lifelink (Damage dealt by this creature also causes you to gain that much life.)
cards.flavor: Some Ravnicans consider carrying a sword to be beneath them, preferring instead a tooth-and-claw escort.
cards.originalText: Lifelink (Damage dealt by this creature also causes you to gain that much life.)

cards.name: Trostani's Judgment
cards.text: Exile target creature, then populate. (Create a token that's a copy of a creature token you control.)
cards.flavor:
"Some cannot be saved as they are, but all can serve the Worldsoul."
—Trostani

rulings.text: You must target a creature to cast Trostani's Judgment. If that creature is an illegal target when Trostani's Judgment tries to resolve, it won't resolve and none of its effects will happen. You won't populate.
If you choose a creature token you control as the target, it will be exiled before you populate and you won't be able to choose that creature to copy.

You can choose any creature token you control for populate. If a spell or ability puts a token onto the battlefield under your control and then instructs you to populate (as Coursers' Accord does), you may choose to copy the token you just created, or you may choose to copy another creature token you control.
If you choose to copy a creature token that's a copy of another creature, the new creature token will copy the characteristics of whatever the original token is copying.
The new creature token copies the characteristics of the original token as stated by the effect that put the original token onto the battlefield.

The new token doesn't copy whether the original token is tapped or untapped, whether it has any counters on it or Auras and Equipment attached to it, or any noncopy effects that have changed its power, toughness, color, and so on.
Any "as [this creature] enters the battlefield" or "[this creature] enters the battlefield with" abilities of the new token will work.
If you control no creature tokens when you populate, nothing will happen.

cards.originalText: Exile target creature, then populate. (Put a token onto the battlefield that's a copy of a creature token you control.)

cards.name: Aquus Steed
cards.text: {2}{U}, {T}: Target creature gets -2/-0 until end of turn.
cards.flavor: In water, it's as graceful as a dolphin. On land, it darts and jerks so unpredictably that few can ride it for long.
cards.originalText: {2}{U}, {T}: Target creature gets -2/-0 until end of turn.

cards.name: Blustersquall
cards.text:
Tap target creature you don't control.
Overload {3}{U} (You may cast this spell for its overload cost. If you do, change its text by replacing all instances of "target" with "each.")
cards.flavor: Weather is more predictable than the Izzet.

rulings.text: If you don't pay the overload cost of a spell, that spell will have a single target. If you pay the overload cost, the spell won't have any targets.
Because a spell with overload doesn't target when its overload cost is paid, it may affect permanents with hexproof or with protection from the appropriate color.
Note that if the spell with overload is dealing damage, protection from that spell's color will still prevent that damage.
Overload doesn't change when you can cast the spell.
Casting a spell with overload doesn't change that spell's mana cost. You just pay the overload cost instead.
Effects that cause you to pay more or less for a spell will cause you to pay that much more or less while casting it for its overload cost, too.
If you are instructed to cast a spell with overload "without paying its mana cost," you can't choose to pay its overload cost instead.

cards.originalText:
Tap target creature you don't control.
Overload {3}{U} (You may cast this spell for its overload cost. If you do, change its text by replacing all instances of "target" with "each.")

cards.name: Cancel
cards.text: Counter target spell.
cards.flavor:
"It is forbidden. Asking why is irrelevant."
—Sergiu, Opal Lake magistrate
cards.originalText: Counter target spell.

cards.name: Chronic Flooding
cards.text:
Enchant land
Whenever enchanted land becomes tapped, its controller puts the top three cards of their library into their graveyard.
cards.flavor: With the Izzet occupied elsewhere, many of their public works fell into disrepair.

rulings.text: Chronic Flooding's ability will trigger whenever the enchanted land becomes tapped for any reason, not just because its controller taps it for mana.
Chronic Flooding becoming attached to a tapped land won't cause its ability to immediately trigger. That land must go from untapped to tapped.

cards.originalText:
Enchant land
Whenever enchanted land becomes tapped, its controller puts the top three cards of his or her library into his or her graveyard.

cards.name: Conjured Currency
cards.text: At the beginning of your upkeep, you may exchange control of Conjured Currency and target permanent you neither own nor control.
cards.flavor: A bargain in Keyhole Downs is always too good to be true.

rulings.text: The only legal target for Conjured Currency's ability is a permanent both owned and controlled by another player, although it doesn't have to be the same player. For example, a permanent owned by an opponent but controlled by your teammate (or another opponent) could be chosen as the target.

The exchange occurs only if Conjured Currency and the target permanent are both on the battlefield and controlled by different players when the ability resolves. In addition, the target permanent must be one you neither own nor control. If any of these things aren't true when the ability tries to resolve, the exchange won't happen and neither permanent will change controllers.

You don't necessarily have to control Conjured Currency when its ability resolves in order for the exchange to happen. If another player has gained control of Conjured Currency while the ability is on the stack, and a third player controls the target (and you don't own it), you may choose to have those two players exchange control of the relevant permanents.

cards.originalText: At the beginning of your upkeep, you may exchange control of Conjured Currency and target permanent you neither own nor control.

cards.name: Crosstown Courier
cards.text: Whenever Crosstown Courier deals combat damage to a player, that player puts that many cards from the top of their library into their graveyard.
cards.flavor: Information travels quickly through Ravnica's network of messengers and thought agents.
cards.originalText: Whenever Crosstown Courier deals combat damage to a player, that player puts that many cards from the top of his or her library into his or her graveyard.

cards.name: Cyclonic Rift
cards.text:
Return target nonland permanent you don't control to its owner's hand.
Overload {6}{U} (You may cast this spell for its overload cost. If you do, change its text by replacing all instances of "target" with "each.")
cards.flavor: The Izzet specialize in unnatural disaster.

rulings.text: If you don't pay the overload cost of a spell, that spell will have a single target. If you pay the overload cost, the spell won't have any targets.
Because a spell with overload doesn't target when its overload cost is paid, it may affect permanents with hexproof or with protection from the appropriate color.
Note that if the spell with overload is dealing damage, protection from that spell's color will still prevent that damage.
Overload doesn't change when you can cast the spell.
Casting a spell with overload doesn't change that spell's mana cost. You just pay the overload cost instead.
Effects that cause you to pay more or less for a spell will cause you to pay that much more or less while casting it for its overload cost, too.
If you are instructed to cast a spell with overload "without paying its mana cost," you can't choose to pay its overload cost instead.

cards.originalText:
Return target nonland permanent you don't control to its owner's hand.
Overload {6}{U} (You may cast this spell for its overload cost. If you do, change its text by replacing all instances of "target" with "each.")

cards.text: Counter target instant spell.
cards.flavor:
"Civilization will subsume us unless we overwhelm it instead."
—Speaker Zegana
cards.originalText: Counter target instant spell.

cards.name: Doorkeeper
cards.text:
Defender
{2}{U}, {T}: Target player puts the top X cards of their library into their graveyard, where X is the number of creatures with defender you control.
cards.flavor: One piercing stare usually convinces thieves to go elsewhere.

rulings.text: The number of creatures with defender you control is counted when the ability resolves.

cards.originalText:
Defender
{2}{U}, {T}: Target player puts the top X cards of his or her library into his or her graveyard, where X is the number of creatures with defender you control.

cards.name: Downsize
cards.text:
Target creature you don't control gets -4/-0 until end of turn.
Overload {2}{U} (You may cast this spell for its overload cost. If you do, change its text by replacing all instances of "target" with "each.")

rulings.text: If you don't pay the overload cost of a spell, that spell will have a single target. If you pay the overload cost, the spell won't have any targets.
Because a spell with overload doesn't target when its overload cost is paid, it may affect permanents with hexproof or with protection from the appropriate color.
Note that if the spell with overload is dealing damage, protection from that spell's color will still prevent that damage.
Overload doesn't change when you can cast the spell.
Casting a spell with overload doesn't change that spell's mana cost. You just pay the overload cost instead.
Effects that cause you to pay more or less for a spell will cause you to pay that much more or less while casting it for its overload cost, too.

cards.originalText:
Target creature you don't control gets -4/-0 until end of turn.
Overload {2}{U} (You may cast this spell for its overload cost. If you do, change its text by replacing all instances of "target" with "each.")

cards.name: Faerie Impostor
cards.text:
Flying
When Faerie Impostor enters the battlefield, sacrifice it unless you return another creature you control to its owner's hand.
cards.flavor: Many Tin Street shops display a sign on the door: "No cloaks allowed."

rulings.text: Returning another creature you control to its owner's hand is optional. You may choose to sacrifice Faerie Impostor, even if you could return a creature.

cards.originalText:
Flying
When Faerie Impostor enters the battlefield, sacrifice it unless you return another creature you control to its owner's hand.

cards.name: Hover Barrier
cards.text: Defender, flying
cards.flavor: As whispers and rumors increased, so did the demand for fail-safe barriers.
cards.originalText: Defender, flying

cards.name: Inaction Injunction
cards.text:
Detain target creature an opponent controls. (Until your next turn, that creature can't attack or block and its activated abilities can't be activated.)
Draw a card.
cards.flavor:
"To prevent action is to prevent transgression."
—Azorius Arrester motto

rulings.text: Activated abilities include a colon and are written in the form "[cost]: [effect]." No one can activate any activated abilities, including mana abilities, of a detained permanent.
The static abilities of a detained permanent still apply. The triggered abilities of a detained permanent can still trigger.
If a creature is already attacking or blocking when it's detained, it won't be removed from combat. It will continue to attack or block.
If a permanent's activated ability is on the stack when that permanent is detained, the ability will be unaffected.
If a noncreature permanent is detained and later turns into a creature, it won't be able to attack or block.

When a player leaves a multiplayer game, any continuous effects with durations that last until that player's next turn or until a specific point in that turn will last until that turn would have begun. They neither expire immediately nor last indefinitely.

cards.originalText:
Detain target creature an opponent controls. (Until your next turn, that creature can't attack or block and its activated abilities can't be activated.)
Draw a card.

cards.name: Inspiration
cards.text: Target player draws two cards.
cards.flavor:
"Day 31: I finally succeeded in my time reversal experiment!
"Day 30: I might have a problem here."
—Journal of the Prime Izmagnus
cards.originalText: Target player draws two cards.

cards.name: Isperia's Skywatch
cards.text:
Flying
When Isperia's Skywatch enters the battlefield, detain target creature an opponent controls. (Until your next turn, that creature can't attack or block and its activated abilities can't be activated.)

rulings.text: Activated abilities include a colon and are written in the form "[cost]: [effect]." No one can activate any activated abilities, including mana abilities, of a detained permanent.
The static abilities of a detained permanent still apply. The triggered abilities of a detained permanent can still trigger.
If a creature is already attacking or blocking when it's detained, it won't be removed from combat. It will continue to attack or block.
If a permanent's activated ability is on the stack when that permanent is detained, the ability will be unaffected.
If a noncreature permanent is detained and later turns into a creature, it won't be able to attack or block.

When a player leaves a multiplayer game, any continuous effects with durations that last until that player's next turn or until a specific point in that turn will last until that turn would have begun. They neither expire immediately nor last indefinitely.

cards.originalText:
Flying
When Isperia's Skywatch enters the battlefield, detain target creature an opponent controls. (Until your next turn, that creature can't attack or block and its activated abilities can't be activated.)

cards.name: Jace, Architect of Thought
cards.text:
+1: Until your next turn, whenever a creature an opponent controls attacks, it gets -1/-0 until end of turn.
−2: Reveal the top three cards of your library. An opponent separates those cards into two piles. Put one pile into your hand and the other on the bottom of your library in any order.
−8: For each player, search that player's library for a nonland card and exile it, then that player shuffles their library. You may cast those cards without paying their mana costs.

rulings.text: Jace's first ability creates a delayed triggered ability that triggers whenever a creature an opponent controls attacks. It doesn't matter which player or planeswalker that creature is attacking.

You pick one of your opponents when Jace's second ability resolves. The ability doesn't target that opponent. All players may see the revealed cards and offer opinions. You (not your opponent) choose which pile is put into your hand and which pile is put on the bottom of your library.
Piles can be empty. If one of the piles is empty, you choose to put all the revealed cards in your hand or on the bottom of your library.
When resolving Jace's third ability, you search each player's library (including yours) and exile the nonland cards before casting any of them.

For each library, the search is complete only when you explicitly say it is. For example, you can look through one player's library, set that library down, look at another player's library, choose a nonland card in the first library, then choose a nonland card in the second library. Don't reveal any cards from those libraries to any other player until you exile them.
You cast the cards by putting them on the stack one at a time, choosing modes, targets, and so on. The last card you cast will be the first one to resolve.
When casting a card this way, ignore timing restrictions based on the card's type. Other timing restrictions, such as "Cast [this card] only during combat," must be followed.
If you can't cast a card, perhaps because there are no legal targets available, or if you choose not to cast one, it will remain exiled. Jace's ability won't allow you to cast it later.

If you cast a card "without paying its mana cost," you can't pay alternative costs such as overload costs. You can pay additional costs such as kicker costs. If the card has mandatory additional costs, you must pay those.
If a card has {X} in its mana cost, you must choose 0 as its value.

foreignNames.name: 思考を築く者、ジェイス

cards.originalText:
+1: Until your next turn, whenever a creature an opponent controls attacks, it gets -1/-0 until end of turn.
-2: Reveal the top three cards of your library. An opponent separates those cards into two piles. Put one pile into your hand and the other on the bottom of your library in any order.
-8: For each player, search that player's library for a nonland card and exile it, then that player shuffles his or her library. You may cast those cards without paying their mana costs.

cards.name: Mizzium Skin
cards.text:
Target creature you control gets +0/+1 and gains hexproof until end of turn.
Overload {1}{U} (You may cast this spell for its overload cost. If you do, change its text by replacing all instances of "target" with "each.")

rulings.text: If you don't pay the overload cost of a spell, that spell will have a single target. If you pay the overload cost, the spell won't have any targets.
Because a spell with overload doesn't target when its overload cost is paid, it may affect permanents with hexproof or with protection from the appropriate color.
Note that if the spell with overload is dealing damage, protection from that spell's color will still prevent that damage.
Overload doesn't change when you can cast the spell.
Casting a spell with overload doesn't change that spell's mana cost. You just pay the overload cost instead.
Effects that cause you to pay more or less for a spell will cause you to pay that much more or less while casting it for its overload cost, too.
If you are instructed to cast a spell with overload "without paying its mana cost," you can't choose to pay its overload cost instead.

cards.originalText:
Target creature you control gets +0/+1 and gains hexproof until end of turn.
Overload {1}{U} (You may cast this spell for its overload cost. If you do, change its text by replacing all instances of "target" with "each.")

cards.name: Paralyzing Grasp
cards.text:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature doesn't untap during its controller's untap step.
cards.flavor:
"Obviously, the Firemind's mission is worth more than a few goblins."
—Pelener, chamberlain of Niv-Mizzet

rulings.text: Paralyzing Grasp may target, and may enchant, an untapped creature. If it does, it will have no effect unless that creature becomes tapped somehow.
The enchanted creature can still be untapped by a spell or ability at other times.

cards.originalText:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature doesn't untap during its controller's untap step.

cards.name: Psychic Spiral
cards.text: Shuffle all cards from your graveyard into your library. Target player puts that many cards from the top of their library into their graveyard.
cards.flavor: An elocutor forces criminals to confess to the laws they merely intended to break.

rulings.text: Psychic Spiral won't be shuffled into your library, and it won't be counted when determining how many cards the target player puts into their graveyard. It will be put into your graveyard after you follow its instructions.
If you cast Psychic Spiral when there are no cards in your graveyard, you'll still shuffle your library.

cards.originalText: Shuffle all cards from your graveyard into your library. Target player puts that many cards from the top of his or her library into his or her graveyard.

cards.name: Runewing
cards.text:
Flying
When Runewing dies, draw a card.
cards.flavor: In the hands of the open-minded, a runewing quill writes wisdom of its own.
cards.originalText:
Flying
When Runewing dies, draw a card.

cards.name: Search the City
cards.text:
When Search the City enters the battlefield, exile the top five cards of your library.
Whenever you play a card with the same name as one of the exiled cards, you may put one of those cards with that name into its owner's hand. Then if there are no cards exiled with Search the City, sacrifice it. If you do, take an extra turn after this one.

rulings.text: To "play a card" is to play that card as a land or cast that card as a spell, whichever is appropriate.
You can put only one card into its owner's hand for each card you play.
If you don't sacrifice Search the City, perhaps because it was destroyed in response to its ability triggering, you won't take an extra turn.

cards.originalText:
When Search the City enters the battlefield, exile the top five cards of your library.
Whenever you play a card with the same name as one of the exiled cards, you may put one of those cards with that name into its owner's hand. Then if there are no cards exiled with Search the City, sacrifice it. If you do, take an extra turn after this one.

cards.name: Skyline Predator
cards.text:
Flash (You may cast this spell any time you could cast an instant.)
Flying
cards.flavor:
"It will dodge your first arrow and flatten you before there's a second."
—Alcarus, Selesnya archer
cards.originalText:
Flash (You may cast this spell any time you could cast an instant.)
Flying

cards.name: Soulsworn Spirit
cards.text:
Soulsworn Spirit can't be blocked.
When Soulsworn Spirit enters the battlefield, detain target creature an opponent controls. (Until your next turn, that creature can't attack or block and its activated abilities can't be activated.)

rulings.text: Activated abilities include a colon and are written in the form "[cost]: [effect]." No one can activate any activated abilities, including mana abilities, of a detained permanent.
The static abilities of a detained permanent still apply. The triggered abilities of a detained permanent can still trigger.
If a creature is already attacking or blocking when it's detained, it won't be removed from combat. It will continue to attack or block.
If a permanent's activated ability is on the stack when that permanent is detained, the ability will be unaffected.
If a noncreature permanent is detained and later turns into a creature, it won't be able to attack or block.

When a player leaves a multiplayer game, any continuous effects with durations that last until that player's next turn or until a specific point in that turn will last until that turn would have begun. They neither expire immediately nor last indefinitely.

cards.originalText:
Soulsworn Spirit is unblockable.
When Soulsworn Spirit enters the battlefield, detain target creature an opponent controls. (Until your next turn, that creature can't attack or block and its activated abilities can't be activated.)

cards.name: Sphinx of the Chimes
cards.text:
Flying
Discard two nonland cards with the same name: Draw four cards.
cards.flavor: "I've dreamt of the future, Isperia. Danger is on the horizon. You must heed my warning."
cards.originalText:
Flying
Discard two nonland cards with the same name: Draw four cards.

cards.name: Stealer of Secrets
cards.text: Whenever Stealer of Secrets deals combat damage to a player, draw a card.
cards.flavor: The Dimir would hire her, if only they knew where she lived. The Azorius would condemn her, if only they knew her name.
cards.originalText: Whenever Stealer of Secrets deals combat damage to a player, draw a card.

cards.name: Syncopate
cards.text: Counter target spell unless its controller pays {X}. If that spell is countered this way, exile it instead of putting it into its owner's graveyard.
cards.flavor: "Patience, mage. Killing you now would be too easy."
cards.originalText: Counter target spell unless its controller pays {X}. If that spell is countered this way, exile it instead of putting it into its owner's graveyard.

cards.name: Tower Drake
cards.text:
Flying
{W}: Tower Drake gets +0/+1 until end of turn.
cards.flavor: The first motion put forth in the pristine Jelenn Column was for severe restrictions on the airspace around New Prahv.
cards.originalText:
Flying
{W}: Tower Drake gets +0/+1 until end of turn.

cards.name: Voidwielder
cards.text: When Voidwielder enters the battlefield, you may return target creature to its owner's hand.
cards.flavor:
"He makes up his own laws, and that's dangerous to all who love peace and prosperity. Kill him on sight."
—Mirela, Azorius hussar

rulings.text: If Voidwielder is the only creature on the battlefield, you'll have to choose it as the target of its ability, although you may choose to not return it to its owner's hand.

cards.originalText: When Voidwielder enters the battlefield, you may return target creature to its owner's hand.

cards.name: Assassin's Strike
cards.text: Destroy target creature. Its controller discards a card.
cards.flavor: When Selesnya missionaries moved into the Shanav Quarter, they faced scorn, ridicule, and ultimately martyrdom.

rulings.text: You must be able to target a creature to cast Assassin's Strike.
If the creature is an illegal target when Assassin's Strike tries to resolve, it won't resolve and none of its effects will happen. Its controller won't discard a card.
If Assassin's Strike resolves but the creature isn't destroyed (perhaps because it regenerated or has indestructible), its controller will discard a card.

cards.originalText: Destroy target creature. Its controller discards a card.

cards.name: Catacomb Slug
cards.flavor:
"The entire murder scene was covered in dripping, oozing slime. No need for a soothsayer to solve that one."
—Pel Javya, Wojek investigator

cards.name: Cremate
cards.text:
Exile target card from a graveyard.
Draw a card.
cards.flavor:
"Without a body, the soul is helpless to fight the terms of our contracts."
—Somhaur, Orzhov pontiff

rulings.text: You must be able to target a card in a graveyard to cast Cremate.
If the target card is no longer in the graveyard when Cremate tries to resolve, it won't resolve and none of its effects will happen. You won't draw a card.

cards.originalText:
Exile target card from a graveyard.
Draw a card.

cards.name: Daggerdrome Imp
cards.text:
Flying
Lifelink (Damage dealt by this creature also causes you to gain that much life.)
cards.flavor: One of the many reasons why open-air markets close at dusk.
cards.originalText:
Flying
Lifelink (Damage dealt by this creature also causes you to gain that much life.)

cards.name: Dark Revenant
cards.text:
Flying
When Dark Revenant dies, put it on top of its owner's library.
cards.flavor: The murderer faced justice in the Azorius courts, but his soul was set free on a technicality.

rulings.text: Dark Revenant's ability isn't optional. However, if Dark Revenant leaves the graveyard before its ability resolves, it won't be put on top of its owner's library.

cards.originalText:
Flying
When Dark Revenant dies, put it on top of its owner's library.

cards.name: Dead Reveler
cards.text: Unleash (You may have this creature enter the battlefield with a +1/+1 counter on it. It can't block as long as it has a +1/+1 counter on it.)
cards.flavor: He's the unlife of the party.

rulings.text: You make the choice to have the creature with unleash enter the battlefield with a +1/+1 counter or not as it's entering the battlefield. At that point, it's too late for a player to respond to the creature spell by trying to counter it, for example.
The unleash ability applies no matter where the creature is entering the battlefield from.
A creature with unleash can't block if it has any +1/+1 counter on it, not just one put on it by the unleash ability.
Putting a +1/+1 counter on a creature with unleash that's already blocking won't remove it from combat. It will continue to block.

cards.originalText: Unleash (You may have this creature enter the battlefield with a +1/+1 counter on it. It can't block as long as it has a +1/+1 counter on it.)

cards.name: Desecration Demon
cards.text:
Flying
At the beginning of each combat, any opponent may sacrifice a creature. If a player does, tap Desecration Demon and put a +1/+1 counter on it.

rulings.text: Players won't know which player or planeswalker Desecration Demon will attack, if any, when deciding whether to sacrifice a creature.

Each opponent in turn order may choose to sacrifice a creature, even if an opponent already chose to sacrifice a creature that combat. Desecration Demon will have a maximum of one +1/+1 counter put on it each combat, no matter how many creatures were sacrificed.

cards.originalText:
Flying
At the beginning of each combat, any opponent may sacrifice a creature. If a player does, tap Desecration Demon and put a +1/+1 counter on it.

cards.name: Destroy the Evidence
cards.text: Destroy target land. Its controller reveals cards from the top of their library until they reveal a land card, then puts those cards into their graveyard.
cards.flavor: Everyone knew the Dimir had done the damage. Everyone suspected the Izzet had hired them.

rulings.text: If the controller of the target land has no land cards in their library, all cards from that library will be revealed and put into their graveyard.

cards.originalText: Destroy target land. Its controller reveals cards from the top of his or her library until he or she reveals a land card, then puts those cards into his or her graveyard.

cards.name: Deviant Glee
cards.text:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature gets +2/+1 and has "{R}: This creature gains trample until end of turn."
cards.flavor: "You just need the right incentive to fulfill my dreams."

rulings.text: Only the controller of the enchanted creature can activate the ability that gives it trample.

cards.originalText:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature gets +2/+1 and has "{R}: This creature gains trample until end of turn."

cards.name: Drainpipe Vermin
cards.text: When Drainpipe Vermin dies, you may pay {B}. If you do, target player discards a card.
cards.flavor: When times are tough, the poor eat the rats. When times are tougher, the rats eat the poor.

rulings.text: You may pay {B} only once. The target player will discard a maximum of one card because of Drainpipe Vermin's ability.

cards.originalText: When Drainpipe Vermin dies, you may pay {B}. If you do, target player discards a card.

cards.name: Grave Betrayal
cards.text: Whenever a creature you don't control dies, return it to the battlefield under your control with an additional +1/+1 counter on it at the beginning of the next end step. That creature is a black Zombie in addition to its other colors and types.

rulings.text: Grave Betrayal doesn't overwrite any previous colors or types. Rather, it adds another color and another creature type.
If the creature is normally colorless, it will simply be black. It won't be both black and colorless.
If a creature you don't control dies during the end step, that creature won't return to the battlefield until the beginning of the next end step.

Each creature you don't control that dies causes a delayed triggered ability to trigger at the beginning of the next end step. If there are multiple such abilities, you can put them on the stack in any order. The creatures will return to the battlefield one at a time as each ability resolves. The last ability you put on the stack will be the first one to resolve.

If the creature card leaves the graveyard before the delayed triggered ability resolves, it won't return to the battlefield. This is also true if the card leaves the graveyard and returns to the graveyard before that ability resolves.

The phrase "with an additional +1/+1 counter on it" means that the creature enters the battlefield with one more +1/+1 counter than it would normally enter the battlefield with. It doesn't keep any counters it had on it when it died.

In a multiplayer game, if more than one player controls a Grave Betrayal and a creature controlled by none of those players dies, each Grave Betrayal will create a delayed triggered ability at the beginning of the next end step. The first such ability to resolve will return the creature. Usually, this will be one controlled by the player furthest from the active player in turn order.

cards.originalText: Whenever a creature you don't control dies, return it to the battlefield under your control with an additional +1/+1 counter on it at the beginning of the next end step. That creature is a black Zombie in addition to its other colors and types.

cards.name: Grim Roustabout
cards.text:
Unleash (You may have this creature enter the battlefield with a +1/+1 counter on it. It can't block as long as it has a +1/+1 counter on it.)
{1}{B}: Regenerate Grim Roustabout.
cards.flavor: He'll point you to your death row seats.

rulings.text: You make the choice to have the creature with unleash enter the battlefield with a +1/+1 counter or not as it's entering the battlefield. At that point, it's too late for a player to respond to the creature spell by trying to counter it, for example.
The unleash ability applies no matter where the creature is entering the battlefield from.
A creature with unleash can't block if it has any +1/+1 counter on it, not just one put on it by the unleash ability.
Putting a +1/+1 counter on a creature with unleash that's already blocking won't remove it from combat. It will continue to block.

cards.originalText:
Unleash (You may have this creature enter the battlefield with a +1/+1 counter on it. It can't block as long as it has a +1/+1 counter on it.)
{1}{B}: Regenerate Grim Roustabout.

cards.name: Launch Party
cards.text:
As an additional cost to cast this spell, sacrifice a creature.
Destroy target creature. Its controller loses 2 life.
cards.flavor: Life's too short to not do the things you love.

rulings.text: If you sacrifice an attacking or blocking creature during the declare blockers step, it won't deal combat damage. If you wait until the combat damage step, but that creature is dealt lethal damage, it'll be destroyed before you get a chance to sacrifice it.
If the target creature is an illegal target when Launch Party tries to resolve, it won't resolve and none of its effects will happen. No player will lose 2 life.
You must sacrifice exactly one creature to cast this spell; you cannot cast it without sacrificing a creature, and you cannot sacrifice additional creatures.
Players can only respond once this spell has been cast and all its costs have been paid. No one can try to destroy the creature you sacrificed to prevent you from casting this spell.

cards.originalText:
As an additional cost to cast Launch Party, sacrifice a creature.
Destroy target creature. Its controller loses 2 life.

cards.name: Mind Rot
cards.text: Target player discards two cards.
cards.flavor: With no memories left to compare to his present situation, Andalum was finally content.
cards.originalText: Target player discards two cards.

cards.name: Necropolis Regent
cards.text:
Flying
Whenever a creature you control deals combat damage to a player, put that many +1/+1 counters on it.
cards.flavor: "Jarad fancies himself king of the undercity, but he's merely king of rot."

rulings.text: If that creature deals combat damage to a player at the same time it's dealt lethal damage (perhaps because it has trample and was blocked), it will die before the triggered ability resolves and puts +1/+1 counters on it.

cards.originalText:
Flying
Whenever a creature you control deals combat damage to a player, put that many +1/+1 counters on it.

cards.name: Ogre Jailbreaker
cards.text:
Defender
Ogre Jailbreaker can attack as though it didn't have defender as long as you control a Gate.
cards.flavor: It took three years for it to occur to him to use the chain as a weapon, but once it did, he made up for lost time.

rulings.text: Defender only matters when Ogre Jailbreaker could be declared as an attacking creature. If Ogre Jailbreaker is already attacking, losing control of your only Gate won't cause Ogre Jailbreaker to leave combat.

cards.originalText:
Defender
Ogre Jailbreaker can attack as though it didn't have defender as long as you control a Gate.

cards.name: Pack Rat
cards.text:
Pack Rat's power and toughness are each equal to the number of Rats you control.
{2}{B}, Discard a card: Create a token that's a copy of Pack Rat.

rulings.text: Pack Rat's first ability counts any creature you control with the creature type Rat, not just Pack Rats.

The token will copy Pack Rat's two abilities. Its power and toughness will be equal to the number of Rats you control (not the number of Rats you controlled when the token entered the battlefield). It will also be able to create copies of itself.

The token won't copy counters on Pack Rat, nor will it copy other effects that have changed Pack Rat's power, toughness, types, color, or so on. Normally, this means the token will simply be a Pack Rat. But if any copy effects have affected that Pack Rat, they're taken into account.

If Pack Rat leaves the battlefield before its activated ability resolves, the token will still enter the battlefield as a copy of Pack Rat, using Pack Rat's copiable values from when it was last on the battlefield.

cards.originalText:
Pack Rat's power and toughness are each equal to the number of Rats you control.
{2}{B}, Discard a card: Put a token onto the battlefield that's a copy of Pack Rat.

cards.name: Perilous Shadow
cards.text: {1}{B}: Perilous Shadow gets +2/+2 until end of turn.
cards.flavor: There are some shadows that even the Dimir fear.
cards.originalText: {1}{B}: Perilous Shadow gets +2/+2 until end of turn.

cards.name: Sewer Shambler
cards.text:
Swampwalk (This creature can't be blocked as long as defending player controls a Swamp.)
Scavenge {2}{B} ({2}{B}, Exile this card from your graveyard: Put a number of +1/+1 counters equal to this card's power on target creature. Scavenge only as a sorcery.)

rulings.text: Exiling the creature card with scavenge is part of the cost of activating the scavenge ability. Once the ability is activated and the cost is paid, it's too late to stop the ability from being activated by trying to remove the creature card from the graveyard.

cards.originalText:
Swampwalk (This creature is unblockable as long as defending player controls a Swamp.)
Scavenge {2}{B} ({2}{B}, Exile this card from your graveyard: Put a number of +1/+1 counters equal to this card's power on target creature. Scavenge only as a sorcery.)

cards.name: Shrieking Affliction
cards.text: At the beginning of each opponent's upkeep, if that player has one or fewer cards in hand, they lose 3 life.
cards.flavor: A gargoyle's voice reaches pitches that will shatter glass and warp bone.

rulings.text: Shrieking Affliction's ability will trigger only if an opponent begins their upkeep with one or fewer cards in hand. The ability will check the number of cards in that player's hand again when it tries to resolve. If that player has two or more cards in hand at that time, that player won't lose life.

cards.originalText: At the beginning of each opponent's upkeep, if that player has one or fewer cards in hand, he or she loses 3 life.

cards.name: Slum Reaper
cards.text: When Slum Reaper enters the battlefield, each player sacrifices a creature.
cards.flavor: It's sent into unguilded districts by the Orzhov to collect the souls of those no one will miss.

rulings.text: When the ability resolves, you may sacrifice Slum Reaper itself. If you control no other creatures, you'll have to sacrifice Slum Reaper.

foreignNames.name: 貧民街の刈り取るもの

cards.originalText: When Slum Reaper enters the battlefield, each player sacrifices a creature.

cards.name: Tavern Swindler
cards.text: {T}, Pay 3 life: Flip a coin. If you win the flip, you gain 6 life.
cards.flavor: Rakdos cultists are her best customers. They never flinch at pain and are seldom good at math.

rulings.text: You can't activate Tavern Swindler's ability if your life total is less than 3. You can activate it if your life total is exactly 3, but it's probably a bad idea. You'll lose the game before the ability resolves.

cards.originalText: {T}, Pay 3 life: Flip a coin. If you win the flip, you gain 6 life.

cards.name: Annihilating Fire
cards.text: Annihilating Fire deals 3 damage to any target. If a creature dealt damage this way would die this turn, exile it instead.
cards.flavor:
"The most impressive performances can be done only once."
—Mote, Rakdos madcap

rulings.text: The creature can still regenerate.
A creature dealt damage by Annihilating Fire that dies this turn will be exiled even if it wasn't the target of Annihilating Fire (say, because the damage was redirected somehow).
A creature dealt damage by Annihilating Fire will be exiled no matter why the creature would die. It could be destroyed by another spell or ability.

cards.originalText: Annihilating Fire deals 3 damage to target creature or player. If a creature dealt damage this way would die this turn, exile it instead.

cards.name: Ash Zealot
cards.text:
First strike, haste
Whenever a player casts a spell from a graveyard, Ash Zealot deals 3 damage to that player.
cards.flavor: "Smarter than death? Let's see you outsmart my mace, necromancer!"

rulings.text: Ash Zealot's ability doesn't allow any player to cast cards from a graveyard. Such cards need another way to be cast, such as the flashback ability.
Ash Zealot's triggered ability will resolve before that spell resolves.
Ash Zealot's ability doesn't trigger if you put a card onto the battlefield from a graveyard (using Grave Betrayal's ability, for example).

cards.originalText:
First strike, haste
Whenever a player casts a spell from a graveyard, Ash Zealot deals 3 damage to that player.

cards.name: Cobblebrute
cards.flavor: The most ancient streets take on a life of their own. A few have decided to move to nicer neighborhoods.

cards.name: Dynacharge
cards.text:
Target creature you control gets +2/+0 until end of turn.
Overload {2}{R} (You may cast this spell for its overload cost. If you do, change its text by replacing all instances of "target" with "each.")
cards.flavor: Nothing evens the odds like a little lightning.

rulings.text: If you don't pay the overload cost of a spell, that spell will have a single target. If you pay the overload cost, the spell won't have any targets.
Because a spell with overload doesn't target when its overload cost is paid, it may affect permanents with hexproof or with protection from the appropriate color.
Note that if the spell with overload is dealing damage, protection from that spell's color will still prevent that damage.
Overload doesn't change when you can cast the spell.
Casting a spell with overload doesn't change that spell's mana cost. You just pay the overload cost instead.
Effects that cause you to pay more or less for a spell will cause you to pay that much more or less while casting it for its overload cost, too.
If you are instructed to cast a spell with overload "without paying its mana cost," you can't choose to pay its overload cost instead.
An overloaded Dynacharge affects only creatures you control at the time it resolves. Creatures you begin to control later in the turn won't get +2/+0.

cards.originalText:
Target creature you control gets +2/+0 until end of turn.
Overload {2}{R} (You may cast this spell for its overload cost. If you do, change its text by replacing all instances of "target" with "each.")

Overload {1}{R} (You may cast this spell for its overload cost. If you do, change its text by replacing all instances of "target" with "each.")

—Vraska

rulings.text: You make the choice to have the creature with unleash enter the battlefield with a +1/+1 counter or not as it's entering the battlefield. At that point, it's too late for a player to respond to the creature spell by trying to counter it, for example.

cards.name: Guild Feud
cards.text: At the beginning of your upkeep, target opponent reveals the top three cards of their library, may put a creature card from among them onto the battlefield, then puts the rest into their graveyard. You do the same with the top three cards of your library. If two creatures are put onto the battlefield this way, those creatures fight each other.

rulings.text: Guild Feud has one target: the opponent. You'll see what creature that player puts onto the battlefield before revealing the top three cards of your library and deciding whether to put a creature onto the battlefield yourself.
If no creatures or only one creature is put onto the battlefield this way, no fight happens.
Players can't cast spells or activate abilities between the creatures being put onto the battlefield and them fighting each other. Notably, you can't respond with a spell like Giant Growth.
Any abilities that trigger when the two creatures enter the battlefield will be put on the stack after the fight, even if one or both creatures die.

cards.originalText: At the beginning of your upkeep, target opponent reveals the top three cards of his or her library, may put a creature card from among them onto the battlefield, then puts the rest into his or her graveyard. You do the same with the top three cards of your library. If two creatures are put onto the battlefield this way, those creatures fight each other.

cards.name: Guttersnipe
cards.text: Whenever you cast an instant or sorcery spell, Guttersnipe deals 2 damage to each opponent.
cards.flavor: He wants to watch Ravnica burn, one soul at a time.

rulings.text: Guttersnipe's triggered ability resolves before the spell that caused it to trigger. It resolves even if that spell is countered.
In a Two-Headed Giant game, Guttersnipe's ability causes the opposing team to lose 4 life.

cards.originalText: Whenever you cast an instant or sorcery spell, Guttersnipe deals 2 damage to each opponent.

cards.name: Lobber Crew
cards.text:
Defender
{T}: Lobber Crew deals 1 damage to each opponent.
Whenever you cast a multicolored spell, untap Lobber Crew.
cards.flavor: It's easier to just aim at everything.

rulings.text: The hybrid spells in the Return to Ravnica set are multicolored, even if you cast them with one color of mana.
You'll untap Lobber Crew before that spell resolves.

cards.originalText:
Defender
{T}: Lobber Crew deals 1 damage to each opponent.
Whenever you cast a multicolored spell, untap Lobber Crew.

Note that if the spell with overload is dealing damage, protection from that spell's color will still prevent that damage.
Overload doesn't change when you can cast the spell.
Casting a spell with overload doesn't change that spell's mana cost. You just pay the overload cost instead.
Effects that cause you to pay more or less for a spell will cause you to pay that much more or less while casting it for its overload cost, too.
If you are instructed to cast a spell with overload "without paying its mana cost," you can't choose to pay its overload cost instead.

cards.originalText:
Street Spasm deals X damage to target creature without flying you don't control.
Overload {X}{X}{R}{R} (You may cast this spell for its overload cost. If you do, change its text by replacing all instances of "target" with "each.")

cards.name: Survey the Wreckage
cards.text: Destroy target land. Create a 1/1 red Goblin creature token.
cards.flavor: Goblins and architects seldom get along.

rulings.text: If the target land is an illegal target when Survey the Wreckage tries to resolve, it won't resolve and none of its effects will happen. You won't get the creature token.

cards.originalText: Destroy target land. Put a 1/1 red Goblin creature token onto the battlefield.

cards.name: Tenement Crasher
cards.text: Haste
cards.flavor: Nothing was going to stop it—not the narrow alleys, not the Boros garrison, and certainly not the four-story Orzhov cathedral.
cards.originalText: Haste

cards.name: Traitorous Instinct
cards.text: Gain control of target creature until end of turn. Untap that creature. Until end of turn, it gets +2/+0 and gains haste.
cards.flavor: Joining the Worldsoul took years of study and meditation. Severing that connection took the snap of Rakdos's fingers.

rulings.text: You may target a creature you already control. You may target a creature that's already untapped.

cards.originalText: Gain control of target creature until end of turn. Untap that creature. Until end of turn, it gets +2/+0 and gains haste.

cards.name: Utvara Hellkite
cards.text:
Flying
Whenever a Dragon you control attacks, create a 6/6 red Dragon creature token with flying.
cards.flavor: The fear of dragons is as old and as powerful as the fear of death itself.

foreignNames.name: ウトヴァラのヘルカイト

cards.originalText:
Flying
Whenever a Dragon you control attacks, put a 6/6 red Dragon creature token with flying onto the battlefield.

cards.name: Vandalblast
cards.text:
Destroy target artifact you don't control.
Overload {4}{R} (You may cast this spell for its overload cost. If you do, change its text by replacing all instances of "target" with "each.")
cards.flavor: Beauty is in the eye of the exploder.

rulings.text: If you don't pay the overload cost of a spell, that spell will have a single target. If you pay the overload cost, the spell won't have any targets.
Because a spell with overload doesn't target when its overload cost is paid, it may affect permanents with hexproof or with protection from the appropriate color.
Note that if the spell with overload is dealing damage, protection from that spell's color will still prevent that damage.
Overload doesn't change when you can cast the spell.
Casting a spell with overload doesn't change that spell's mana cost. You just pay the overload cost instead.
Effects that cause you to pay more or less for a spell will cause you to pay that much more or less while casting it for its overload cost, too.
If you are instructed to cast a spell with overload "without paying its mana cost," you can't choose to pay its overload cost instead.

cards.originalText:
Destroy target artifact you don't control.
Overload {4}{R} (You may cast this spell for its overload cost. If you do, change its text by replacing all instances of "target" with "each.")

cards.name: Viashino Racketeer
cards.text: When Viashino Racketeer enters the battlefield, you may discard a card. If you do, draw a card.
cards.flavor: "You may call me a fool, selling this stuff on Orzhov turf. Well, you need to be a little reckless to survive."

foreignNames.name: ヴィーアシーノのゆすり屋

cards.originalText: When Viashino Racketeer enters the battlefield, you may discard a card. If you do, draw a card.

cards.name: Aerial Predation
cards.text: Destroy target creature with flying. You gain 2 life.
cards.flavor: In the towering trees of the Samok Stand and the predators that guard them, the might of the Ravnican wild has returned.

rulings.text: You must be able to target a creature with flying to cast Aerial Predation.
If the creature with flying is an illegal target when Aerial Predation tries to resolve, it won't resolve and none of its effects will happen. You won't gain 2 life.

cards.originalText: Destroy target creature with flying. You gain 2 life.

cards.name: Archweaver
cards.text: Reach, trample
cards.flavor: The silk of the archweavers adds structural integrity to otherwise unstable Izzet building sites.
cards.originalText: Reach, trample

cards.name: Axebane Guardian
cards.text:
Defender
{T}: Add X mana in any combination of colors, where X is the number of creatures with defender you control.
cards.flavor: Only a worthy few are permitted within the sentient forest known as Axebane.

rulings.text: Axebane Guardian's activated ability is a mana ability. It doesn't use the stack and can't be responded to. The number of creatures with defender you control is counted, and the color(s) of mana produced chosen, immediately after the ability is activated when the ability resolves.

cards.originalText:
Defender
{T}: Add X mana in any combination of colors to your mana pool, where X is the number of creatures with defender you control.

cards.name: Axebane Stag
cards.flavor:
"When the spires have burned and the cobblestones are dust, he will take his rightful place as king of the wilds."
—Kirce, Axebane guardian

cards.name: Brushstrider
cards.text: Vigilance
cards.flavor: Magistrate Ludy agreed to designate land for the brushstriders only after several broken windows and dozens of missing blini-cakes.
cards.originalText: Vigilance

cards.name: Centaur's Herald
cards.text: {2}{G}, Sacrifice Centaur's Herald: Create a 3/3 green Centaur creature token.
cards.flavor: The farther they go from Vitu-Ghazi, the less willing the crowd is to part for them.

rulings.text: Once you activate the ability of Centaur's Herald, it's too late for a player to respond by trying to destroy it or otherwise stop you from sacrificing it.
You can only sacrifice Centaur's Herald once, so it's not possible to activate its ability more than once.

cards.originalText: {2}{G}, Sacrifice Centaur's Herald: Put a 3/3 green Centaur creature token onto the battlefield.

cards.name: Chorus of Might
cards.text: Until end of turn, target creature gets +1/+1 for each creature you control and gains trample.
cards.flavor:
"In each of us is the strength of all of us."
—Trostani

rulings.text: The number of creatures you control is counted only when Chorus of Might resolves.

cards.originalText: Until end of turn, target creature gets +1/+1 for each creature you control and gains trample.

cards.name: Deadbridge Goliath
cards.text: Scavenge {4}{G}{G} ({4}{G}{G}, Exile this card from your graveyard: Put a number of +1/+1 counters equal to this card's power on target creature. Scavenge only as a sorcery.)
cards.flavor: Some Golgari insects live for centuries—and they never stop growing.

rulings.text: Exiling the creature card with scavenge is part of the cost of activating the scavenge ability. Once the ability is activated and the cost is paid, it's too late to stop the ability from being activated by trying to remove the creature card from the graveyard.

cards.originalText: Scavenge {4}{G}{G} ({4}{G}{G}, Exile this card from your graveyard: Put a number of +1/+1 counters equal to this card's power on target creature. Scavenge only as a sorcery.)

cards.name: Death's Presence
cards.text: Whenever a creature you control dies, put X +1/+1 counters on target creature you control, where X is the power of the creature that died.
cards.flavor:
"We traffic in flesh, not souls. Still, it's a shame to let anything go to waste."
—Cevraya, Golgari shaman

rulings.text: X is the power of that creature as it last existed on the battlefield.

cards.originalText: Whenever a creature you control dies, put X +1/+1 counters on target creature you control, where X is the power of the creature that died.

cards.text: Scavenge {5}{G} ({5}{G}, Exile this card from your graveyard: Put a number of +1/+1 counters equal to this card's power on target creature. Scavenge only as a sorcery.)
cards.flavor: The Street Swarm is the labor class that drives the Golgari's endless cycle of life and death.

rulings.text: Exiling the creature card with scavenge is part of the cost of activating the scavenge ability. Once the ability is activated and the cost is paid, it's too late to stop the ability from being activated by trying to remove the creature card from the graveyard.
